metadata.case_name: Petition No. 128 of 1957 (Building Contractors v. Respondents)

facts.text: Petitioners are a firm of building contractors.

In December 1956, petitioners entered into a contract with the Military Engineering Services Department of the Government for the construction of certain buildings known as Married accommodation at Ambala Cantonment.
Petitioners received a sum of Rs. 32,000 on January 31, 1957, as advance.
Tenders were called for and received for executing works for a lump sum; tender of petitioners dated December 15, 1956 accepted by Deputy Chief Engineer for lump sum of Rs. 9,74,961.

On February 14, 1957, the assessing authority, Jullundur District issued a notice intimating petitioners that as they had failed to apply for registration under s. 7 of the Act, assessment would be made under s. 18, sub-s. (2), for periods commencing from April 1, 1955, onwards, calling upon them to produce account books and attend hearing on February 16, 1957.
Petitioners filed present petition under Art. 32 challenging legality of assessment proceedings.

legal_issues.text: Validity of provisions of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948 imposing tax on supply of materials in construction works treating it as a sale.
Whether the building contract was one and indivisible, or a combination of agreement for sale of materials and agreement for work and labour.
Whether petitioners are 'dealers' under s. 2(d) of the Act.
Whether definition of turnover in s. 2(j) clause (ii) taxes supply of materials without reference to sale of goods.

petitioner_arguments.text: Legislature of Province of Punjab had no power under Entry 48 List II Sch. VII Govt. of India Act, 1935 to impose tax on supply of materials in construction works as there was no sale in fact or law of those materials; provisions ultra vires.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 48 List II Govt. of India Act 1935; State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: In definition of turnover in s. 2(j) cl. (ii), no reference to sale of goods.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948 s. 2(j) cl. (ii)

petitioner_arguments.text: Petitioners are building contractors not engaged in business of selling or supplying goods, hence not dealers under s. 2(d); tax only on dealers under s. 4.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948 s. 2(d), s. 4

respondent_arguments.text: Building contract entered by petitioners with Government comprised distinct agreement for sale of materials.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 33 of General Conditions of Contracts

court_reasoning.text: Question concluded by decision in State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley: expression 'sale of goods' in Entry 48 has same meaning as in Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930; in building contract no sale of materials; Provincial Legislature no power to tax.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No sale of materials as such in building contract.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence shows contract is lump sum for construction of nine blocks; no agreement for sale of materials as such.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tenders for lump sum; acceptance for lump sum Rs. 9,74,961.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 33 vests materials in Government temporarily to ensure quality, not sale; surplus materials revert to contractor; similar to Tripp v. Armitage and Reid v. Macbeth Gray.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Terms ensure materials of right sort used, not purchase.

court_reasoning.text: Charging s.4(1) taxes sales; turnover includes supply in contracts as taxable turnover.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Obvious intention to include supply of materials.

court_reasoning.text: If supply regarded as sale, building contractors are dealers engaged in sale of materials.

holdings.text: No sale of materials used by petitioners in constructions; no tax could be levied thereon; provisions of Act ultra vires.
Contract is one indivisible lump sum contract for construction, not separate sale of materials.

precedents_cited.case_name: The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held no sale of goods in building contract under Entry 48; Provincial Legislature no power to tax.
Approval of materials does not constitute acceptance or sale; property passes only when fixed.
Approval and marking of materials does not pass property apart from main construction contract.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions defining contract, dealer, sale, turnover; liability to tax; impugned for taxing materials in construction as sale.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition for enforcement of fundamental rights.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Limits provincial power to tax sales of goods.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art. 32 allowed; provisions of East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948 held ultra vires to extent they impose tax on supply of materials in construction works treating as sale; no tax leviable on petitioners.
outcome.relief_granted: Challenge to assessment proceedings upheld; no tax on materials in construction contract.

key_quotes.text: "in a building contract there is no sale of materials as such, and that accordingly the Provincial Legislature had no power to impose a tax thereon under Entry 48."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is impossible on this evidence to hold that there was any agreement for sale of the materials as such by the petitioners to the Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Terms such as these and those in r. 33 quoted above are usually inserted in building contracts with the object of ensuring that materials of the right sort are used in the construction and not with the intention of purchasing them."
key_quotes.speaker: court
